visuals.title: Phasor Addition: V₁ + V₂ = V_sum
visuals.description: Two phasors V₁ = 4∠30° and V₂ = 3∠(-60°) are added as vectors. The sum (gold) is the resultant from the origin.

visuals.title: Worked Example: Result of Adding Two Sinusoids
visuals.description: The time-domain signals v₁(t) = 4cos(ωt+30°), v₂(t) = 3cos(ωt-60°), and their sum v(t) = 5cos(ωt-6.87°).

visuals.title: Derivative Property: Multiplying by jω Rotates +90°
visuals.description: The original phasor V = 5∠30° (blue) and its derivative jωV at ω = 100 (red). The derivative has magnitude 500 and phase 120° — rotated by exactly 90°.

visuals.title: Capacitor: Current Leads Voltage by 90°
visuals.description: For a capacitor, i = C·dv/dt. The derivative property means the current phasor is rotated +90° from the voltage. The current peaks a quarter cycle BEFORE the voltage.

visuals.title: Interactive: Graphical Phasor Addition
visuals.description: Drag two phasors on the complex plane and see their sum computed both graphically (tip-to-tail) and algebraically in real time.

visuals.title: Interactive: Series RC Circuit — Voltage Addition
visuals.description: Watch how the source voltage equals the sum of V_R and V_C. The individual voltage drops have different phases but add up (as phasors) to match the source.
